items.title: Why document.write() is bad
items.content:
#â€‹622 â€” January 20, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Why Not document.write()? â€” Many moons ago, document.write was a mainstay of client-side JavaScript code, but it's long been considered a bad practice â€“ why? Harry digs in, noting that it â€œguarantees both a blocking fetch and a blocking execution, which holds up the parser for far longer thanÂ necessaryâ€.

Harry Roberts

New:Â The WebAssembly JavaScript Promise Integration API â€” A technical explanation from the V8 team on a new API to let WebAssembly apps bridge the synchronous / asynchronous gap of expectations around external functionality (consider that many apps are written synchronously, but modern Web APIs are usually asynchronous). JSPI helps bridge both worlds and can be tested via a flag inÂ Chrome.

McCabe, Michaud, Rezvov, Dahl / V8 Team

Break the Programming Mold with Dependency Injection â€” Keep your code on the cutting edge with dependency injection in JavaScript. Check out Snykâ€™s guide that gives a breakdown of what dependency injection is, when you should use it, and what popular JavaScript frameworks itâ€™sÂ implemented.

Snyk sponsor

Why Is My Jest Suite So Slow? â€” Jest is known for its speed and simplicity so the author was surprised at how quickly his teamâ€™s test suite was slowing down. This is a write up of the ensuing investigation along with the improvements that slashed test runningÂ time.

Steven Lemon

Bun v0.5 Released â€” Bun is another JavaScript runtime taking the world by storm and a level of Node compatibility has been baked in from the start. v0.5 adds support for node:readline, workspaces, a node:dns shim, and network socket creation support such that more Node.js-based database libraries work out of theÂ box.

Ashcon Partovi

IN BRIEF:

  • The â–¶ï¸ latest episode of the JS Party podcast tackles 'the rise and fall' of JavaScript frameworks and the modern trend towards smaller ones.

  • The folks at NodeSource have put together a top 10 list of Node open-source projects 'to keep an eye on' in 2023.

  • Aurelia 2 is now in beta.

RELEASES:

  • â­ï¸ esbuild 0.17.0
    â†³ Popular bundler. Note that this is a key release with backwards incompatibleÂ changes.

  • Inertia.js 1.0
    â†³ Build SPAs for any backend.

  • React Native 0.71

  • Remix 1.10.0
    â†³ Popular full stack framework.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ğŸ¨ Â Building an Accessible Theme Picker â€” An attractively presented, easy to follow tutorial for a handy siteÂ feature.

Sarah L. Fossheim

Fixing a Memory Leak in a Production Node.js App â€” Kent encountered a variety of weird memory and CPU usage spikes in his Node-powered app and decided to figure out what was going on. This post walks through his complete journey, with plenty of side problems encountered along the way, before discovering the root cause was where he least expectedÂ it.

Kent C Dodds

Build a Mobile-Responsive Telehealth Pager App Using Streamâ€™s Chat API â€” Build a responsive chat app with emojis/reactions, built-in GIF support, ability to edit/delete messages, direct & group chat, andÂ more.

Stream sponsor

ğŸ“Š Â A Beginnerâ€™s Guide to Chrome Tracing â€” For when you want to go deeper than the Performance tab. With tracing, you can record what a browser is up to far behind theÂ scenes.

Nolan Lawson

Handling Errors Like a Pro in TypeScript â€” â€œLearn the design pattern I use to handle errors and write cleanerÂ code.â€

Kolby Sisk

A Beginner's Guide to async/await with Examples
James Hibbard

10 Mistakes to Avoid When Starting with Vue 3
Fotis Adamakis

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

RoughNotation: Cute Animated 'Rough' Text Annotations â€” Uses Rough.js (itself a project worth checking out) to get a hand-drawn look. Lots of nice interactive examples on the page showing a variety of annotation styles (boxes, underlines, circles..)

Preet Shihn

Free Website Speed Test: Does Your Site Meet Google's Core WebÂ Vitals? â€” Get an in-depth technical analysis of your site and learn how to make it fast. Rank higher in Google & deliver greatÂ UX.

DebugBear sponsor

Modern Errors: Handle Errors in a Simple, Stable, Consistent Way â€” Create error classes, wrap or aggregate errors, or use one of several plugins to do things like print bug reporting info, print stack traces, or more. Happy in both Node and theÂ browser.

ehmicky

Shifty: A Small, Fast Tweening Engine â€” All it does is tweening. Itâ€™s a low level animation solution that you can integrate into any rendering mechanism of your choice. The examples here demonstrate it well as it can be used for â€˜animatingâ€™ things in an unconventional sense. GitHubÂ repo.

Jeremy Kahn

Barba.js: For Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages â€” You certainly canâ€™t say the projectâ€™s homepage doesnâ€™t show off all of its features! For such a dramatic set of effects, things feel smooth and.. surprisingly tolerable ğŸ˜ GitHubÂ repo.

De Rosa, Michel, et al.

Rete.js 1.5: A Framework for Visual Programming â€” Create a node-based editor in the browser and apply logic. Check out these demos on CodePen. GitHubÂ repo.

Vitaliy Stoliarov

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. UseÂ Shortcut

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

gpu-io: GPU-Accelerated ComputingÂ Library â€” for physics simulations and other mathematical calculations. A neat look at the power of WebGL. SeveralÂ examples.

Amanda Ghassaei

  • Chart.js 4.2
    â†³ Simple Canvas-based charts. (Samples.)

  • Serialize JavaScript 6.0.1
    â†³ Serialize JS to a JSON superset.

  • axios-retry 3.4
    â†³ Axios plugin that retries failedÂ requests.

  • Axios 1.2.3 â€“ Popular HTTP client library.

  • Commander.js 10.0 â€“ Node.js CLIs made easy.

  • Mineflayer 4.7 â€“ JS API for Minecraft bots.

  • Wretch 2.4 â€“ Fetch API wrapper with niceties.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

items.title: Java-Script Jarre
items.content:
#â€‹621 â€” January 13, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of JS 2022 â€” The State of JS is one of the JavaScript ecosystemâ€™s most popular surveys and this time 39,471 folks took part giving us a snapshot of the tools, technologies, and language features people are using (or not using!) Thereâ€™s a lot to go through, but here are some keyÂ points:

  • top-level await is the most newly adopted featureÂ recently.
  • The JavaScript / TypeScript balance shows a majority of developers using TypeScript overÂ JS.
  • Express remains by far the most popular backend framework with Nest, Fastify, Strapi, and Koa following somewhatÂ behind.
  • Other interesting results can be found in JS pain points, what is currently missing from JS, and the 'Awards' for stand out items (complete with snazzy visualÂ effects).

Devographics

ğŸ§ˆ Retire your Legacy CMS with ButterCMS â€” ButterCMS is your new content backend. Weâ€™re SaaS so we host, maintain, and scale the CMS. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated SaaS Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free for 30Â days.

ğŸ§ˆ ButterCMS sponsor

ğŸ—£Â Is TypeScript Worth It? â€” Time saver or waste of time? The relationship between TypeScript and JavaScript remains a complex one. An extensive discussion took place on Hacker News this week and, notably, TypeScript PM Daniel Rosenwasser popped up to respond to some of theÂ concerns.

Hacker News

IN BRIEF:

  • You'll be aware of JavaScript's strict mode but one developer thinks we need a stricter mode to fix several other syntax issues.

  • Publint is an online tool for 'linting' live npm packages to see if they are packaged correctly, as a way to ensure maximum compatibility acrossÂ environments.

RELEASES:

  • Node v19.4.0 and v18.13.0 (LTS)

  • Commander.js 9.5
    â†³ Node.js command-line interface toolkit.

  • Angular 15.1

  • Pixi.js 7.1 â€“ Fast 2D on WebGL engine.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The Gotcha of Unhandled Promise Rejections â€” A rough edge with promises that can sneak up on you. Jake looks at a â€˜gotchaâ€™ around unhandled promise rejections and how to work aroundÂ it.

Jake Archibald

HTML with Superpowers: The Guidebook â€” A free resource introducing Web Components, what they are, and what problems theyâ€™re trying to solve. You can see the Guidebook directlyÂ here.

Dave Rupert

With Retool You Ship Apps Fast with 100+ Perfectly Crafted UIÂ Components â€” The fast way for devs to build and share internal tools. Teams at companies like Amazon, DoorDash & NBC collaborate around custom-built Retool apps to solve internalÂ workflows.

Retool sponsor

Everything About React's 'Concurrent Mode' Features â€” An in-depth, example-led exploration of Concurrent Mode (now more a set of features integrated into React 18 than a distinctÂ 'mode').

Henrique Yuji

Using GitHub Copilot for Unit Testing? â€” Even if you find the idea of a AI tool like Copilot writing production code distasteful, it may have a place in speeding up writingÂ tests.

Ianis Triandafilov

How to Destructure Props in Vue (Composition API) â€” How to correctly destructure props object in a Vue component while maintaining theÂ reactivity.

Dmitri Pavlutin

Using Inline JavaScript Modules to Prevent CSS Blockage
Stoyan Stefanov

How to Build a GraphQL Server with Deno
Andy Jiang

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Gluon: Framework for Creating Desktop Apps from Sites â€” A new approach for building desktop apps on Windows and Linux from Web sites using Node (or Deno) and already installed browsers (Chromium or Firefox). Initial macOS support has just been addedÂ too.

Gluon

Structura.js: Lightweight Library for Immutable State Management â€” â€ It is based on the idea of structural sharing. The library is very similar to Immer.js, but it has some advantages overÂ it.â€

Giuseppe Raso

Tuple, a Lightning-Fast Pairing Tool Built for RemoteÂ Developers â€” High-resolution, crystal-clear screen sharing, low-latency remote control, and less CPU usage than you'd thinkÂ possible.

Tuple sponsor

Bay.js: A Lightweight Library for Web Components â€” Makes it easy to create web components that can be reused across projects. It also boasts performant state changes and secure eventÂ binding.

Ian Dunkerley

Twify: Scaffold a Tailwind CSS Project with a Single Command â€” You can use your preferred package manager and it supports creating projects with Next.js, Nuxt 2/3, SvelteKit, Remix, Angular, andÂ more.

Kazi Ahmed

Lazy Brush 2.0: A Library for Smooth Pointer Drawing â€” Allow your users to draw smooth curves and straight lines with your mouse, finger or any pointing device. This long standing library has just migrated to TypeScript and gained a new â€˜frictionâ€™ option to customize the feel. GitHubÂ repo.

Jan Hug

â—Â Mafs: React Components for Interactive Math â€” Build interactive, animated visualizations using declarative code with illustrative demos like bezierÂ curves. The documentation is fantastic â€“ check out how easy it is to make plots. Or just head to the GitHubÂ repo.

Steven Petryk

Are You Looking for a New Observability Tool?

TelemetryHub by Scout sponsor

Hyphenopoly 5.0: A Polyfill for Client-Side Hyphenation â€” An interesting use of WebAssemblyÂ here.

Mathias Nater

  • visx 3.0
    â†³ D3-powered visualization React components.

  • Atrament 3.0
    â†³ Library for drawing and handwriting on a canvas element.

  • HLS.js 1.3
    â†³ Library to play HLS (HTTP Live Streaming) in browsers, with MSEÂ support.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Backend Engineer, TypeScript (Berlin / Remote) â€” Thousands of people love our product (see Trustpilot for yourself). Join the team behind it and help us scale.Â ğŸš€
Feather

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ¶Â Ã‰coute la musique..

Oxygene Pt 4, as Performed by JavaScript â€” This is fun. Dittytoy is a simple, JavaScript-powered online generative music tool and someone has put together a surprisingly faithful rendition of perhaps one of the best known instrumental synth songs ever, all the way fromÂ 1976.

Dittytoy

items.title: Looking at both 2022 and 2023
items.content:
#â€‹620 â€” January 6, 2023

Read on the Web

We're back for 2023 ğŸ˜€ As is our tradition, we're taking a quick look back at the past year â€“ this time led by a few choice retrospectives, then followed by the most popular articles and tools included in JavaScript Weekly in 2022. There's sure to be some things you missed or want to revisit - enjoy!
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸŒŸÂ The 2022 JavaScript Rising Stars â€” For the seventh time, Michael Rambeau kicks off our year with a roundup of â€˜trending projectsâ€™ in the JavaScript space. Bun takes the top spot for 2022, but weâ€™ll leave the rest for you to check out. A few guest authors also share their opinions on theÂ ecosystem.

Michael Rambeau et al.

Evan You Looks at 2022 and 2023 â€” Youâ€™ll know Evan for Vue.js and Vite and here he recaps what happened in the Vue world in 2022 (like Vue 3.x becoming the new default version) and what we can expect in 2023, including the mysteriously named Vapor Mode.. Weâ€™re also warned Vue 2.x has one year before it reachesÂ EOL.

Evan You

ğŸ§ˆ Retire your Legacy CMS with ButterCMS â€” ButterCMS is your new content backend. Weâ€™re SaaS so we host, maintain, and scale the CMS. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated SaaS Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free forÂ 30Â days.

ğŸ§ˆ ButterCMS sponsor

Six JavaScript Projects to Watch in 2023 â€” A reasonable selection, focused on newer, more cutting edge, but also very promising projects (including the aforementioned Bun).

AsyncBanana

LOOKING BACK AND FORWARD:

  • Michael Shilman writes about the future for Storybook inÂ 2023.

  • Ryan Carniato ponders where JS frameworks are headed inÂ 2023.

  • ğŸ“… â–¶ï¸ 10 JavaScript conferences to consider attending thisÂ year.

  • Some other 2022 roundups and reflections: Cassidy Williams, Igalia Web Platform Team, Dave Rupert, StÃ©phanie Walter, Pawel Grzybek, Stephanie Eckles, Michelle Barker, Rachel Andrew, Remy Sharp, Ahmad Shadeed, the HTTP protocol ğŸ˜†

RELEASES:

  • Spacetime 7.4 â€“ Lightweight timezone library.

  • Lerna 6.4 â€“ JS monorepo build tool.

  • TestCafe 2.2 â€“ End-to-end Web testing.

  • Vuetify 3.1 â€“ Vue component framework.

ğŸ“’Â Top Articles & Tutorials of 2022

As determined by their popularity in JavaScript Weekly.

1.Â Douglas Crockford: "The best thing we can do today to JavaScript is to retire it." â€” The most popular link of the year was to an interview with the author of JavaScript: The Good Parts (and discoverer-of-sorts of JSON) where he explained the benefits of code reading, why we need better languages, and how he wonâ€™t â€œwrite about JavaScriptÂ again.â€

Evrone

2.Â Ecma International Approved ECMAScript 2022 â€” The second most popular item of the year was a bit more positive, with Ecma making ECMAScript 2022 a standard. Dr. Axel brought us up to speed with what this meant at a practical level. Youâ€™ll already be using some of these features â€“ this move just tied up theÂ formalities.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

â–¶Â Â Whiskey Web and Whatnot: Your New Favorite JavaScript Podcast â€” A fireside chat with your favorite devs. Guests include Wes Bos, Charlie Gerard, Chris Coyier, and KellyÂ Vaughn.

Whiskey Web and Whatnot sponsorpodcast

3.Â JS Function Composition: Whatâ€™s The Big Deal? â€” Jamesâ€™ articles on JavaScript fundamentals are always popular and last year we got a fresh one focusing on a common activity: function composition. â€œWhatâ€™s the bigÂ deal?â€ heÂ asks.

James Sinclair

4.Â AbortController is Your Friend â€” AbortController provides a way to abort web requests at any point without waiting for a response but itâ€™s possible to twist it into other use cases, as we sawÂ here.

Sam Thorogood

5.Â Ten Common JavaScript Issues Developers Face â€” A good old-fashioned list. If youâ€™ve been working with JavaScript for many years, these are potholes you (probably) know to avoid but thereâ€™s enough to chew on hereÂ otherwise.

Ryan J. Peterson

6.Â A Pipe Operator for JS: Introduction and Use Cases â€” Many developers feel a pipe operator is missing from JavaScript. Luckily there's a pipeline operator proposal at stage 2 in TC39. Dr. Axel explains why youâ€™d want this and how it couldÂ work.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

7.Â Patterns.dev: Modern Web App Design Patterns â€” A free book you can download in PDF format or enjoy on the Web. Learn about lots of fundamentals, from how different styles of rendering or importing resources work to performance optimizations and caseÂ studies.

Lydia Hallie, Addy Osmani, and Others

8.Â Decorators for ES6 Proposal Reached Stage 3 at TC39 â€” It's a few years in the making, but a decorators proposal conditionally made it to stage 3 and people were very excited. Fingers crossed we see more from this inÂ 2023.

Ecma TC39

ğŸ› Â Top Code & Tools of 2022

As determined by their popularity in JavaScript Weekly.

1.Â Rome Formatter: Super Fast JavaScript Formatting â€” I liked the image for this enough to want to include it again ;-) As of 2023, Rome (now at version 11) remains an ambitious project that sets out to replace a lot of JS tools in one hit with the initial focus being on Prettier-esque code formatting, as well asÂ linting. Compiling, bundling, and testing features are scheduled to appear throughoutÂ 2023.

Rome Team

2.Â TypeScript 4.6 Released â€” Not a lot to say here, as TypeScript is always popular, and it's now up to version 4.9, but with v4.6 it took a step forward by being able to detect more syntax errors in plain old JavaScript, a benefit for all JavaScript-developing VS Code users, atÂ least.

Daniel Rosenwasser

Dynaboard: The Pro-Code Web App Builder Made for Developers â€” Build high performance public and private web apps in a collaborative â€” code forward â€” WYSIWYGÂ environment.

Dynaboard sponsor

3.Â Vite 4.0 Released â€” This was only a month ago, too. From the same creator as Vue.js, Vite is an exciting piece of frontend tooling offering lots of goodies out of the box. We look forward to more Vite news inÂ 2023.

Evan You and Vite Contributors

4.Â Lexical: An Extensible Text Editor Library â€” Out of Meta came a new text editor framework putting accessibility, performance, and reliability at its heart. At only 22KB gzipped and with React 18+ support (but vanilla is also OK), it reminded us of Draft.js but they say it's the "next generation" and Meta is already replacing Draft.js with Lexical in their internalÂ apps.

Meta / Facebook

5.Â Bun: A (Still) Interesting New JavaScript Runtime â€” Bun appeared in summer 2022 as a new JavaScript runtime built not around V8 (like Node.js or Deno are) but WebKit/Appleâ€™s JavaScriptCore. It includes its own bundler, transpiler, task runner, and npm client, but most significantly boasts huge performance improvements over existing options and supported a lot of Node and Web APIs out of theÂ box.

Jarred Sumner

6.Â JSON Crack: Visualize JSON Data in Graph Form â€” Got JSON, want to view it? This is a neat tool for working with and displaying JSON data structures. You can play with it online, embed the graphs into your site, or download them for furtherÂ use.

Aykut SaraÃ§

Stuck on Node 10? Need to Upgrade but Donâ€™t Have Time? ContactÂ UsÂ ğŸš€

UpgradeJS.com | Node and JavaScript Upgrade Services sponsor

7.Â Shader Park: Create Interactive 2D and 3D Shaders with JavaScript â€” An open source Web-based platform, community, and library for simplifying the mystifying world of shaders and GPUs by letting you create them procedurally with JavaScript. Note: This site is heavy on the browser given its use of WebGL, so may not be suitable for everyÂ device.

Blankensmith and Whidden

8.Â Axios 1.0: The Popular HTTP Client Library/API â€” With 98k GitHub stars and a presence in numerous thousands of package.json files, Axios remains very popular and itâ€™s amazing it only hit 1.0 in 2022. The Fetch API has taken much of Axios' thunder but, like jQuery, Axios still wraps up a lot of functionality into a broadly liked API. (OfficialÂ homepage.)

Axios Project

ğŸ’» Jobs

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Backend Engineer, TypeScript (Berlin / Remote) â€” Thousands of people love our product (see Trustpilot for yourself). Join the team behind it and help us scale.Â ğŸš€
Feather

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

We're back to normal service as of next week! If you've got anything you'd like to submit for our consideration, hit reply and let us know.

#â€‹620 â€” January 6, 2023


Read on the Web



We're back for 2023 ğŸ˜€ As is our tradition, we're taking a quick look back at the past year â€“ this time led by a few choice retrospectives, then followed by the most popular articles and tools included in JavaScript Weekly in 2022. There's sure to be some things you missed or want to revisit - enjoy!
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team


    
    

JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
ğŸŒŸÂ The 2022 JavaScript Rising Stars â€” For the seventh time, Michael Rambeau kicks off our year with a roundup of â€˜trending projectsâ€™ in the JavaScript space. Bun takes the top spot for 2022, but weâ€™ll leave the rest for you to check out. A few guest authors also share their opinions on theÂ ecosystem.
Michael Rambeau et al. 


  
  
Evan You Looks at 2022 and 2023 â€” Youâ€™ll know Evan for Vue.js and Vite and here he recaps what happened in the Vue world in 2022 (like Vue 3.x becoming the new default version) and what we can expect in 2023, including the mysteriously named Vapor Mode.. Weâ€™re also warned Vue 2.x has one year before it reachesÂ EOL.
Evan You 


  
  
ğŸ§ˆ Retire your Legacy CMS with ButterCMS â€” ButterCMS is your new content backend. Weâ€™re SaaS so we host, maintain, and scale the CMS. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated SaaS Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free forÂ 30Â days.
ğŸ§ˆ ButterCMS sponsor


  
  
Six JavaScript Projects to Watch in 2023 â€” A reasonable selection, focused on newer, more cutting edge, but also very promising projects (including the aforementioned Bun).
AsyncBanana 


LOOKING BACK AND FORWARD:
Michael Shilman writes about the future for Storybook inÂ 2023.
Ryan Carniato ponders where JS frameworks are headed inÂ 2023.
ğŸ“… â–¶ï¸ 10 JavaScript conferences to consider attending thisÂ year.
Some other 2022 roundups and reflections: Cassidy Williams, Igalia Web Platform Team, Dave Rupert, StÃ©phanie Walter, Pawel Grzybek, Stephanie Eckles, Michelle Barker, Rachel Andrew, Remy Sharp, Ahmad Shadeed, the HTTP protocol ğŸ˜†


RELEASES:
Spacetime 7.4 â€“ Lightweight timezone library.
Lerna 6.4 â€“ JS monorepo build tool.
TestCafe 2.2 â€“ End-to-end Web testing.
Vuetify 3.1 â€“ Vue component framework.


ğŸ“’Â Top Articles & Tutorials of 2022





As determined by their popularity in JavaScript Weekly.





  
  
1.Â Douglas Crockford: "The best thing we can do today to JavaScript is to retire it." â€” The most popular link of the year was to an interview with the author of JavaScript: The Good Parts (and discoverer-of-sorts of JSON) where he explained the benefits of code reading, why we need better languages, and how he wonâ€™t â€œwrite about JavaScriptÂ again.â€
Evrone 


  
  
2.Â Ecma International Approved ECMAScript 2022 â€” The second most popular item of the year was a bit more positive, with Ecma making ECMAScript 2022 a standard. Dr. Axel brought us up to speed with what this meant at a practical level. Youâ€™ll already be using some of these features â€“ this move just tied up theÂ formalities.
Dr. Axel Rauschmayer 




  
  
â–¶Â Â Whiskey Web and Whatnot: Your New Favorite JavaScript Podcast â€” A fireside chat with your favorite devs. Guests include Wes Bos, Charlie Gerard, Chris Coyier, and KellyÂ Vaughn.
Whiskey Web and Whatnot sponsorpodcast







  
  
3.Â JS Function Composition: Whatâ€™s The Big Deal? â€” Jamesâ€™ articles on JavaScript fundamentals are always popular and last year we got a fresh one focusing on a common activity: function composition. â€œWhatâ€™s the bigÂ deal?â€ heÂ asks.
James Sinclair 


  
  
4.Â AbortController is Your Friend â€” AbortController provides a way to abort web requests at any point without waiting for a response but itâ€™s possible to twist it into other use cases, as we sawÂ here.
Sam Thorogood 


  
  
5.Â Ten Common JavaScript Issues Developers Face â€” A good old-fashioned list. If youâ€™ve been working with JavaScript for many years, these are potholes you (probably) know to avoid but thereâ€™s enough to chew on hereÂ otherwise.
Ryan J. Peterson 


  
  
6.Â A Pipe Operator for JS: Introduction and Use Cases â€” Many developers feel a pipe operator is missing from JavaScript. Luckily there's a pipeline operator proposal at stage 2 in TC39. Dr. Axel explains why youâ€™d want this and how it couldÂ work.
Dr. Axel Rauschmayer 


  
  
7.Â Patterns.dev: Modern Web App Design Patterns â€” A free book you can download in PDF format or enjoy on the Web. Learn about lots of fundamentals, from how different styles of rendering or importing resources work to performance optimizations and caseÂ studies.
Lydia Hallie, Addy Osmani, and Others 


  
  
8.Â Decorators for ES6 Proposal Reached Stage 3 at TC39 â€” It's a few years in the making, but a decorators proposal conditionally made it to stage 3 and people were very excited. Fingers crossed we see more from this inÂ 2023.
Ecma TC39 


ğŸ› Â Top Code & Tools of 2022





As determined by their popularity in JavaScript Weekly.




  





  
  
1.Â Rome Formatter: Super Fast JavaScript Formatting â€” I liked the image for this enough to want to include it again ;-) As of 2023, Rome (now at version 11) remains an ambitious project that sets out to replace a lot of JS tools in one hit with the initial focus being on Prettier-esque code formatting, as well asÂ linting. Compiling, bundling, and testing features are scheduled to appear throughoutÂ 2023.
Rome Team 


  
  
2.Â TypeScript 4.6 Released â€” Not a lot to say here, as TypeScript is always popular, and it's now up to version 4.9, but with v4.6 it took a step forward by being able to detect more syntax errors in plain old JavaScript, a benefit for all JavaScript-developing VS Code users, atÂ least.

Dynaboard: The Pro-Code Web App Builder Made for Developers â€” Build high performance public and private web apps in a collaborative â€” code forward â€” WYSIWYGÂ environment.

3.Â Vite 4.0 Released â€” This was only a month ago, too. From the same creator as Vue.js, Vite is an exciting piece of frontend tooling offering lots of goodies out of the box. We look forward to more Vite news inÂ 2023.

items.title: A new jQuery release for Xmas
items.content:
#â€‹619 â€” December 16, 2022

Read on the Web

ğŸ„ This is the final issue of the year â€“ we'll be back on January 6, 2023. We hope you have a fantastic holiday season, whether or not you are celebrating, and we'll see you for a look back at 2022 in the first week of January :-)
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

JavaScript Weekly

Announcing SvelteKit 1.0 â€” Svelte is a virtual DOM-free, compiled ahead of time, frontend UI framework with many fans. SvelteKit introduces a framework and tooling around Svelte to build complete webapps. This release post explains some of its approach and how it differs to otherÂ systems.

The Svelte Team

Dr. Axel Tackles Two Proposals: Iterator Helpers and Set Methods â€” Hereâ€™s something to get your teeth into! Dr. Axel takes on two promising ECMAScript proposals and breaks down what theyâ€™re about and why theyâ€™ll (hopefully) become useful to JavaScript developers. The first tackles iterator helpers (new utility methods for working with iterable data) and the second tackles Set methods which will extend ES6â€™s Set object.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ§ˆ Retire your Legacy CMS with ButterCMS â€” ButterCMS is your new content backend. Weâ€™re SaaS so we host, maintain, and scale the CMS. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated SaaS Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free for 30Â days.

ğŸ§ˆ ButterCMS sponsor

ğŸ† Â The Best of Node Weekly in 2022 â€” In this weekâ€™s issue of Node Weekly (our Node.js-focused sister newsletter) we looked back at the most popular items of the year, including the Tao of Node, an array of JavaScript testing best practices, and the most popular Node.js frameworks inÂ 2022.

Node Weekly Newsletter

jQuery 3.6.2 Released â€” Humor me. You might not be using jQuery anymore, but it's (still) the most widely deployed JavaScript library and itâ€™s fantastic to see it beingÂ maintained.

jQuery Foundation

IN BRIEF:

  • Node 19.3.0 (Current) has been released to bring npm up to v9.2. Breaking changes in v9.x warrant this update and the release post explains the current policy around npm's ongoing inclusion in Node.

  • Æ› The Glasgow Haskell Compiler (GHC) has gained a new JavaScript backend meaning the reference Haskell compiler can now emit JavaScript and be used more easily to build front-end apps.

  • GitHub is rolling out secrets scanning to all public repos for free.

  • The New Stack reflects on 2022 as a 'golden year' for JavaScript and some of the developments we'veÂ seen. We'll be doing our own such roundup in the nextÂ issue.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js 16.19.0 (LTS) and 14.21.2 (LTS)

  • Chart.js 4
    â†³ Canvas-based chart library. (Samples.)

  • PouchDB 8.0
    â†³ CouchDB-inspired syncing database.

  • SWR 2.0 â€“ React data-fetching library.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Why Cypress v12 is a Big Deal â€” A practical example-led love letter of sorts to how the latest version of the popular Cypress â€˜test anything that runs in a browserâ€™ library makes testing frontend apps smoother thanÂ before.

Gleb Bahmutov

Five Challenges to Building an Isomorphic JS Library â€” When it comes to JavaScript, â€œisomorphicâ€ means code or libraries that run both on client and server runtimes with minimalÂ adaptations.

Nick Fahrenkrog (Doordash)

â–¶Â Â A Podcast for Candid Chats on Product, Business & Leadership â€” Join Postlight leaders & guests as they discuss topics like running great meetings & creating solid productÂ launches.

The Postlight Podcast sponsor

Next, Nest, Nuxtâ€¦ Nust? â€” â€œThis blog post is for everyone looking for their new favorite JavaScript backend framework.â€ If the names of frameworks are all starting to blur together in your head, this is for you. Marius explains just what systems like Next and Gatsby do and touches on a fewÂ differences.

Marius Obert (Twilio)

Calculating the Maximum Diagonal Distance in a Given Collection of GeoJSON Features using Turf.js â€” This isÂ cool. Turf.js is a geospatial analysis library, by theÂ way.

Piotr Jaworski

Optimize Interaction to Next Paint â€” How to optimize for the experimental Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric â€”Â a way to assess a pageâ€™s overall responsiveness to userÂ interactions.

Jeremy Wagner & Philip Walton (Google)

Need to Upgrade to React 18.2? Donâ€™t Have Time? Our Experts CanÂ Help â€” Stuck in dependency hell? Weâ€™ve been there. Hire our team of experts to upgrade deps, gradually paying off techÂ debt.

UpgradeJS.com - JavaScript Upgrade Services by OmbuLabs sponsor

How We Configured pnpm and Turborepo for OurÂ Monorepo
Pierre-Louis Mercereau (NHost)

Rendering Emails with Svelte
Gautier Ben Aim

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Wretch 2.3: A Wrapper Around fetch with an Intuitive Syntax â€” A long standing, mature library that makes fetch a little more extensible with a fluent API. Check theÂ examples.

Julien Elbaz

SWR 2.0: Improved React Hooks for DataÂ Fetching â€” The second major release of SWR (Stale-While-Revalidate) includes new mutation APIs, new developer tools, as well as improved support for concurrentÂ rendering.

Ding, Liu, Kobayashi, and Xu

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

vanilla-tilt.js 1.8: A Smooth 3D Tilting Effect Library â€” No dependencies and simple to use and customize. GitHubÂ repo.

È˜andor Sergiu

visx: Airbnb's Low Level Visualization React Components â€” Bring your own state management, animation library, or CSS-in-JS.. visx can slot into any React setup. Demos.

Airbnb

Scene.js 1.7: A CSS Timeline-Based Animation Library â€” Plenty of examples on the site. Has components for React, Vue andÂ Svelte.

Daybrush

  • PortalVue 3.0
    â†³ Feature-rich portal plugin for Vue 3.

  • Kea 3.1
    â†³ Composable state management for React.

  • jest-puppeteer 6.2
    â†³ Run tests using Jest + Puppeteer.

  • NodeBB 2.7 â€“ Node.js based forum software.

  • Pino 8.8 â€“ Fast JSON-oriented logger.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Software Engineer â€” Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're always looking for more exceptionalÂ engineers.
Stickermule

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸÂ And one for fun

Snow.js: Add a Snow Effect to a Web Page â€” Well, itâ€™s that time of the year (in some parts of the world!) If youâ€™re more interested in how the effect is made, itâ€™s inspired by this CodePenÂ example built around some fancyÂ CSS.

Or if you're a bit more childish, you could always put Fart.js on your site.. ğŸ™ˆ

Merry Christmas to you all and we'll see you again inÂ 2023!
